task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab professional profile and current employment details
task_1.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, where he focuses on developing generative AI products. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)) Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue a Ph.D. in Physics and Astronomy at Ohio University. His doctoral research centered on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with myelinated dendrites. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

After completing his Ph.D., Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a postdoctoral researcher. There, he worked on designing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders like Parkinson's disease, including the development of Coordinated Reset (CR) stimulation techniques. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. Following CODA's closure in 2022 due to funding challenges, he joined Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. In 2024, he moved to Amazon Rufus to work on generative AI products. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab is also an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University and has contributed as an editor to the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for significant contributions in clinical medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional roles, he actively engages in independent research projects, referred to as "night science," focusing on problems at the intersection of nonlinear dynamics, computer science, and AI. One of his notable publications from this endeavor is "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," published in Scientific Reports in 2022. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab maintains a personal website where he shares updates on his professional journey and research interests. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_2.query_used: Search Google for news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose work has been recognized in various academic and professional contexts. In 2019, as a doctoral student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, he received the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award. This grant enabled him to present his research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons, at the APS annual meeting in Boston. During the conference, he had the opportunity to meet notable physicists, including 2018 Nobel Laureate Donna Strickland. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, Khaledi Nasab was invited to deliver a colloquium at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics. His talk, titled "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements," focused on the stochastic dynamics of tree networks relevant to certain sensory neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

Beyond his academic achievements, Khaledi Nasab has been active in addressing challenges faced by international students. In 2017, he authored a column in *Science* magazine titled "Standing up to fear," where he discussed the impact of U.S. immigration policies on international scholars and emphasized the need for institutional support. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

His research contributions include studies on neuronal network dynamics and desynchronization techniques. Notably, he co-authored a 2021 paper titled "Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neural Networks by Random Reset Stimulation," which explores methods to counteract excessive neuronal synchrony associated with neurological disorders like epilepsy and Parkinson's disease. ([patrinum.ch](https://patrinum.ch/record/489579?utm_source=openai))

In 2023, Khaledi Nasab shared insights on job interview strategies through a Medium article, offering guidance on navigating the interview process and emphasizing the importance of negotiation skills. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai))

Overall, Ali Khaledi Nasab's work spans significant research in physics and neuroscience, as well as active engagement in discussions on academic and professional development.

task_3.query_used: Search corporate registries and business databases for companies associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Based on the available information, there are no records indicating that Ali Khaledi Nasab is associated with any companies in corporate registries or business databases. The search results primarily highlight his academic and professional background.

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist who completed his doctoral studies at Ohio University. During his time there, he received an American Physical Society Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the annual APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, he was invited to give a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics, discussing emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

Professionally, Ali Khaledi Nasab has held positions as a Senior Researcher at Amazon in Seattle, United States, and as a Researcher at the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he has authored articles on Medium, including topics such as job interview strategies and book recommendations. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/?utm_source=openai))

Given the absence of information linking him to any corporate entities, it appears that his focus has been primarily on academic research and professional roles within established organizations.

task_4.query_used: Search academic databases and Google Scholar for publications or research by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_4.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist with a diverse academic and professional background. He earned his Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University, where his research focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with myelinated dendrites. His doctoral work included studies on emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

After completing his Ph.D., Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a postdoctoral researcher. There, he contributed to the development of coordinated reset stimulation techniques aimed at desynchronizing neural networks, with potential applications in treating neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease. His work in this area led to several publications, including studies on the long-lasting desynchronization effects of coordinated reset stimulation improved by random jitters. ([med.stanford.edu](https://med.stanford.edu/tass-lab/publications.html?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, Dr. Khaledi Nasab transitioned to the tech industry, joining Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. He later moved to Amazon Rufus, focusing on generative AI products. His expertise spans physics, neuroscience, machine learning, deep learning, nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been recognized for his contributions to science and technology. He has received awards such as the American Physical Society Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award and has been invited to speak at various academic institutions. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai), [ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his research, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been an advocate for international students and scientists. He authored a piece in *Science* magazine titled "Standing up to fear," discussing the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. during the 2017 travel ban. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive list of his publications and further details about his work, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_5.query_used: Search court records and legal databases for litigation involving Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
After searching court records and legal databases, I found no litigation involving an individual named "Ali Khaledi Nasab." It's possible that such records are not publicly available, the individual has not been involved in any legal proceedings, or the name may be spelled differently in legal documents.

However, I did find a case involving a similar name: "Khaledi." In the 2003 Texas Court of Appeals case *Khaledi v. Global Trading Ltd HAR*, Heydar "Shaun" Khaledi appealed a temporary injunction related to a business dispute among three brothers who co-owned multiple companies. The dispute centered on the buyout of Shaun's business interests and subsequent consulting agreements. ([caselaw.findlaw.com](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/tx-court-of-appeals/1109873.html?utm_source=openai))

If you have more specific information or alternative spellings of the name, I can assist further in locating relevant legal records.

task_10.query_used: Search conference speaker lists and event databases featuring Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_10.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has actively participated in various academic conferences and colloquia, focusing on the dynamics of excitable tree networks and their applications to sensory neurons. Notable engagements include:

- **Colloquium at the College of Wooster (October 3, 2017):** Nasab delivered a talk titled "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements," discussing the spontaneous activity in tree-like networks relevant to sensory neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

- **American Physical Society (APS) Annual Meeting (March 2019):** He presented a paper on "Dynamics of Excitable Tree Networks: Application to Sensory Neurons" and received an APS Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award to attend the conference in Boston. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

These engagements highlight Nasab's contributions to the field of physics and his focus on understanding the principles of sensory neuron dynamics.

task_12.query_used: Search archived web pages and cached content mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab using Wayback Machine
task_12.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose research focuses on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons. He earned his Ph.D. in Physics & Astronomy from Ohio University, where he was advised by Dr. Alexander Neiman. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2019, Khaledi Nasab received a Student Travel Award from the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics, enabling him to present his work on "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons" at the APS annual meeting in Boston. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai)) His research employs theoretical and computational methods to understand spike generation and information coding in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies.

In 2017, he delivered a colloquium at the College of Wooster titled "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements," discussing the stochastic dynamics of tree networks relevant to certain sensory neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

Khaledi Nasab has also contributed to the academic community by developing a MATLAB program for generating adjacency matrices of random tree networks, facilitating research in network dynamics. ([mathworks.com](https://www.mathworks.com/matlabcentral/fileexchange/67890-random-tree-generator?utm_source=openai))

Beyond his research, he has shared insights on professional development, including strategies for successful job interviews, emphasizing the importance of tailored applications and receptiveness to feedback. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai))

As of 2024, Khaledi Nasab is a Senior Researcher at Amazon in Seattle and a Researcher at the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, specializing in generative AI products. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University and has a strong academic background in network dynamics and computational neuroscience.  No red flags were identified in the provided OSINT sources.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

* Currently employed at Amazon Rufus, working on generative AI products.
* Completed a Ph.D. in Physics and Astronomy at Ohio University, focusing on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks, specifically in sensory neurons with myelinated dendrites.

**Business & Financial Activity**

* No specific business or financial affiliations were identified beyond his employment at Amazon Rufus.

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

* No litigation or criminal records were found associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab. A legal case involving a similar surname (Khaledi) was found, but it is unrelated.

**Academic / Public Recognition**

* Received the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award in 2019.
* Presented research at the APS annual meeting in Boston in 2019.
* Gave a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster.
* Authored or co-authored 23 publications with 426 citations according to Exaly.
* Research interests include machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics as per his Google Scholar profile.
* Published research on depolarizing echo chambers in social networks.


**Online / Social Presence**

* Maintains a personal website: [alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)
* Has a Google Scholar profile: [‪Ali Khaledi-Nasab‬ - ‪Google Scholar‬](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai)
* Published an article on Medium: [An Introduction to a successful job interview | by Ali Khaledi Nasab | Medium](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai)
* No readily identifiable profiles were found on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram.


**Other Notable Mentions**

* Originally from Iran, moved to the United States in 2014.


### Risk Profile

Based on the available OSINT data, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**.  He has a strong academic background, positive professional recognition, and no indications of legal or criminal issues.

flagged_issues: The report omits several key details from the retrieval evidence including: postdoctoral work at Stanford, employment at CODA Biotherapeutics, adjunct professor role at Ohio University, contribution to Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health (2024 PROSE Award), and his 'Standing up to fear' Science magazine article about immigration policies. The report also fails to mention specific research publications like 'Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neural Networks by Random Reset Stimulation' (2021). Some timeline details are vague or missing.
judgement.revised_report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, specializing in generative AI products. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University and has a strong academic background in network dynamics and computational neuroscience. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014. No red flags were identified in the provided OSINT sources.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

* Currently employed at Amazon Rufus (since 2024), working on generative AI products¹
* Previously worked at Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a research scientist in Network Capacity Planning (2022-2024)¹
* Worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on epilepsy treatments (2021-2022, company closed due to funding challenges)¹
* Completed postdoctoral research at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, developing Coordinated Reset (CR) stimulation techniques for treating neurological disorders like Parkinson's disease¹
* Holds an adjunct professor position in physics at Ohio University¹
* Completed Ph.D. in Physics and Astronomy at Ohio University, focusing on collective dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons with myelinated dendrites¹

**Business & Financial Activity**

* No specific business or financial affiliations were identified beyond his employment history
* No property ownership records found⁶

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

* No litigation or criminal records were found associated with Ali Khaledi Nasab⁵
* A legal case involving a similar surname (Khaledi v. Global Trading Ltd HAR, 2003) was found but is unrelated⁵

**Academic / Public Recognition**

* Received the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award in 2019²
* Presented research at the APS annual meeting in Boston in 2019, where he met 2018 Nobel Laureate Donna Strickland²
* Gave a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster in 2017 titled "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements"²
* Authored or co-authored 23 publications with 426 citations according to Exaly⁹
* Research interests include machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics⁷
* Published research on "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge" in Scientific Reports (2022)¹⁹
* Co-authored "Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neural Networks by Random Reset Stimulation" (2021)²
* Contributing editor to the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for significant contributions in clinical medicine¹
* Authored "Standing up to fear" in Science magazine (2017), discussing challenges faced by international students during the U.S. travel ban²⁴

**Online / Social Presence**

* Maintains a personal website: [alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)¹
* Has a Google Scholar profile: [Ali Khaledi-Nasab - Google Scholar](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai)⁷
* Published an article on Medium (2023): "An Introduction to a successful job interview"²
* No readily identifiable profiles were found on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram⁷

**Other Notable Mentions**

* Originally from Iran, moved to the United States in 2014¹
* Engages in independent research projects called "night science," focusing on problems at the intersection of nonlinear dynamics, computer science, and AI¹
* No patents or trademarks registered to his name⁹
* Not found on any sanctions lists or watchlists¹¹

### Risk Profile

Based on the available OSINT data, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**. He has a strong academic background, positive professional recognition, progressive career trajectory through reputable institutions (Stanford, Amazon), and no indications of legal, criminal, or compliance issues.

### Citations
¹ Personal website (alikhaledi.com)  
² Ohio Forum articles (2017, 2019)  
³ Stanford Medicine Tass Lab publications  
⁴ Academia.edu - "Standing up to fear"  
⁵ Court records search  
⁶ Property records search  
⁷ Google Scholar profile  
⁸ Medium article (2023)  
⁹ Exaly.com author profile  
¹⁰ ArXiv publication  
¹¹ Sanctions lists search

task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab professional profile and current employment details
task_1.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed at Amazon Rufus, where he focuses on developing generative AI products. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)) Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue a Ph.D. in Physics and Astronomy at Ohio University. His doctoral research centered on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with myelinated dendrites. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

After completing his Ph.D., Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a postdoctoral researcher. There, he worked on designing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders like Parkinson's disease, including the development of Coordinated Reset (CR) stimulation techniques. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. Following CODA's closure in 2022 due to funding challenges, he joined Amazon Web Services (AWS) as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. In 2024, he moved to Amazon Rufus to work on generative AI products. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab is also an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University and has contributed as an editor to the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for significant contributions in clinical medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional roles, he actively engages in independent research projects, referred to as "night science," focusing on problems at the intersection of nonlinear dynamics, computer science, and AI. One of his notable publications from this endeavor is "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," published in Scientific Reports in 2022. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab maintains a personal website where he shares updates on his professional journey and research interests. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_2.query_used: Search Google for news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose work has been recognized in various academic and professional contexts. In 2019, as a doctoral student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, he received the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award. This grant enabled him to present his research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons, at the APS annual meeting in Boston. During the conference, he had the opportunity to meet notable physicists, including 2018 Nobel Laureate Donna Strickland. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, Khaledi Nasab was invited to deliver a colloquium at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics. His talk, titled "Emergent Stochastic Oscillations and Signal Detection in Tree Networks of Excitable Elements," focused on the stochastic dynamics of tree networks relevant to certain sensory neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

Beyond his academic achievements, Khaledi Nasab has been active in addressing challenges faced by international students. In 2017, he authored a column in *Science* magazine titled "Standing up to fear," where he discussed the impact of U.S. immigration policies on international scholars and emphasized the need for institutional support. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

His research contributions include studies on neuronal network dynamics and desynchronization techniques. Notably, he co-authored a 2021 paper titled "Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neural Networks by Random Reset Stimulation," which explores methods to counteract excessive neuronal synchrony associated with neurological disorders like epilepsy and Parkinson's disease. ([patrinum.ch](https://patrinum.ch/record/489579?utm_source=openai))

In 2023, Khaledi Nasab shared insights on job interview strategies through a Medium article, offering guidance on navigating the interview process and emphasizing the importance of negotiation skills. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai))

Overall, Ali Khaledi Nasab's work spans significant research in physics and neuroscience, as well as active engagement in discussions on academic and professional development.

task_4.query_used: Search academic databases and Google Scholar for publications or research by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_4.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist with a diverse academic and professional background. He earned his Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University, where his research focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with myelinated dendrites. His doctoral work included studies on emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

After completing his Ph.D., Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a postdoctoral researcher. There, he contributed to the development of coordinated reset stimulation techniques aimed at desynchronizing neural networks, with potential applications in treating neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease. His work in this area led to several publications, including studies on the long-lasting desynchronization effects of coordinated reset stimulation improved by random jitters. ([med.stanford.edu](https://med.stanford.edu/tass-lab/publications.html?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, Dr. Khaledi Nasab transitioned to the tech industry, joining Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. He later moved to Amazon Rufus, focusing on generative AI products. His expertise spans physics, neuroscience, machine learning, deep learning, nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been recognized for his contributions to science and technology. He has received awards such as the American Physical Society Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award and has been invited to speak at various academic institutions. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai), [ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his research, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been an advocate for international students and scientists. He authored a piece in *Science* magazine titled "Standing up to fear," discussing the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. during the 2017 travel ban. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive list of his publications and further details about his work, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_5.query_used: Search court records and legal databases for litigation involving Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
After searching court records and legal databases, I found no litigation involving an individual named "Ali Khaledi Nasab." It's possible that such records are not publicly available, the individual has not been involved in any legal proceedings, or the name may be spelled differently in legal documents.

However, I did find a case involving a similar name: "Khaledi." In the 2003 Texas Court of Appeals case *Khaledi v. Global Trading Ltd HAR*, Heydar "Shaun" Khaledi appealed a temporary injunction related to a business dispute among three brothers who co-owned multiple companies. The dispute centered on the buyout of Shaun's business interests and subsequent consulting agreements. ([caselaw.findlaw.com](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/tx-court-of-appeals/1109873.html?utm_source=openai))

If you have more specific information or alternative spellings of the name, I can assist further in locating relevant legal records.

citations.title: KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR (2003) | FindLaw

task_7.data:
I was unable to locate specific social media profiles for an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab on platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram. However, according to his Google Scholar profile, Ali Khaledi-Nasab is affiliated with Amazon and has research interests in machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

task_9.query_used: Search trademark and patent databases for intellectual property registered to Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_9.data:
After reviewing available sources, I did not find any patents or trademarks registered to Ali Khaledi Nasab. However, he has an extensive academic background with 23 publications and 426 citations, reflecting his active engagement in research. ([exaly.com](https://exaly.com/author/5034433/ali-khaledi-nasab?utm_source=openai))

One of his notable works includes a study titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," co-authored with Christopher Brian Currin and Sebastián Vallejo Vera. This research explores mechanisms to mitigate polarization in social networks. ([export.arxiv.org](https://export.arxiv.org/abs/2101.04079?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Ali Khaledi Nasab has been recognized for his contributions to the field of physics. In 2019, he received an American Physical Society Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

While there are no records of patents or trademarks under his name, his scholarly work and recognition in the academic community highlight his significant contributions to his field.

task_11.query_used: Search sanctions lists and watchlists for any entries matching Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_11.data:
After reviewing available sanctions lists and watchlists, there is no record of an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab. It's possible that the name may be spelled differently or that the individual is not listed under current sanctions.

For the most accurate and up-to-date information, you can consult the U.S. Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons List (SDN List). This list is regularly updated and can be accessed through OFAC's official website.

Please note that sanctions lists are subject to change, and it's advisable to consult official sources for the most current information.
